Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Reproductive Consequences of Cooperation in a Polygynous Ant
Award.AbstractNarration:
Social groups are built around cooperation, in which individuals work together to benefit the group. Human success as a social species is built around this mutual benefit, but we know little about its evolution and maintenance. Cooperative groups risk being vulnerable to cheating, if a group member takes advantage of the effort of others to secure a disproportionate amount of resources. In groups of relatives, these effects can be offset by kinship. However, the costs and benefits of cooperation among non-relatives are more difficult to assess and explain. The California harvester ant provides a rare opportunity to examine the costs and benefits of cooperation among non-relatives. In this species, some queens practice primary polygyny, in which unrelated queens cooperatively build a new nest and rear offspring together, forming what is essentially a multi-family colony. The proposed work will investigate what ecological conditions favor the evolution of cooperation in this species, and how these cooperative societies deal with the possibility of cheating by some group members. The proposed research will be combined with undergraduate training, in which students participate in field and laboratory research. This builds on a record of mentoring excellence by the principal investigator and graduate student. The researchers will also work in conjunction with the local parks department to provide educational materials highlighting this unusual ant population. This research is fundamental to our understanding of social evolution, and may provide insight into the issues of cooperation and conflict in human societies.

Prior work has shown that colonies in the polygynous population have lower reproductive output than those in a nearby population without polygyny. This suggests polygyny may be a functional response to local environmental constraints. Polygynous colonies also face issues of cheating, if reproduction is non-equitably distributed among queens. Interpretation of these findings is limited, because the polygynous and single-queen populations investigated so far are in different environments. The researchers will quantify the reproductive output of single- versus multi-queen colonies within a single population, to determine whether variation in reproduction is environmentally driven, or an intrinsic colony attribute. This analysis will be combined with a food supplement experiment, to determine whether reproduction in polygynous colonies is resource limited. Finally, relative queen contributions to reproduction versus worker production within polygynous colonies will be analyzed via microsatellites, to determine whether queens share in reproduction equitably. If not, this suggests that subtle cheating may be taking place within these cooperative associations. Data will be stored locally and on ASU server space for a minimum of 5 years, with the expectation of permanently archiving them. Data will be indexed and made available to an open source data depository after publication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An important question for social biology is why groups of non-relatives might form cooperative relationships. There are multiple theoretical models addressing this question, but few experimental contexts where we can actually examine the costs and benefits of non-kin cooperation. In most ant species new nests are started by individual queens, and so the colony itself is a family group. In some populations, however, unrelated queens form cooperative associations during nest establishment that remain intact through the lifespan of the colony, a social strategy known as primary polygyny. Cooperation by these queens has profound effects on survival and reproductive outcomes, both for the queens themselves and for the colony. To date, studies examining the fitness consequences primary polygyny have focused on the benefits cooperation provides for individual queen survival and early colony growth. However, these benefits may be offset by limitations that sharing the resources of a single nest may provide on individual queen reproduction. These balancing costs and benefits likely vary across different environments, leading to the question of how ecology helps shape cooperation.

To better understand the ecological drivers and reproductive consequences of queen cooperation, we compared the reproductive success of polygynous versus single-queen colonies in the harvester ant Pogonomyrmex californicus. Colonies of this species vary across locations in presence of the two different social strategies, with some sites containing mostly multi-queen and others with primarily single-queen colonies. Sites in between the two extremes show mixes of both nesting strategies. We captured and quantified the reproductive offspring produced by colonies across the entire mating season and across multiple years for a primarily polygynous, a single-queen and a mixed site. Both polygynous and single-queen colonies at the mainly polygynous site had lower reproductive output than those at the predominantly single-queen site, suggesting that polygyny creates a reproductive cost, and that the success of queen cooperation is influenced by ecological conditions. This finding was supported by results at the mixed sites. Colony-level reproduction was similar for colonies of both social types, so that queens in polygynous colonies had lower per-capita reproduction. Despite this, multi-queen colonies in the mixed site had stronger worker activity and tighter reproductive regulation than single queen colonies, which may represent a strategy at colony maturity to tailor reproduction around that could increase colony lifespan.

The site dominated by multi-queen colonies had evidence of resource limitation coupled with higher competition, pressures that can favor the evolution of queen cooperation. Colonies were denser at the multi-queen site, and those colonies located most closely to others were less likely to reproduce. Additionally, resource supplementation of colonies in the polygynous site increased their reproductive investment levels to that of colonies in the solitary queen population. Our collective findings suggest that cooperative queens suffer a substantial reproductive cost from resource sharing with other queens, however this cost may be offset by survival benefits, production of a more robust workforce and a more regulated growth and reproductive trajectory. These benefits may only be realized in a difficult, resource-limited environment.

Finally, we used microsatellite markers to examine how evenly polygynous queens share worker and reproductive production with nest-mate queens. The vast majority of queens contributed in relatively equal proportion to worker versus reproductive production. However, there was a low frequency of queens that under-produced workers and over-produced male reproductive offspring. This suggests that cheating by reproducing queens is possible, but uncommon. The high proportion of cooperative queens in this system makes it an ideal model for studies on the evolution and maintenance of non-kin cooperation.

This project provided valuable lab and field research experience for several undergraduate students, most of whom had never been involved in research. Seven undergraduates assisted in the field component of the study, where they were trained in ecological survey methods, ant identification, and reproductive investment quantification. An additional seven undergraduate students also assisted in the genetic analysis portion of the study, where they were trained in DNA extraction, PCR, and microsatellite analysis. Several of these students went on to complete and honors thesis, utilizing the training the received on this project, and almost all continued on to graduate education and/or STEM careers.
